name: Socrates
worldview_values: Wisdom through questioning, moral knowledge, the examined life
example_lines: I know that I know nothing
The unexamined life is not worth living
Are we not obligated to seek wisdom in all our choices?

name: Kant
example_lines: Act only according to maxims you could will to be universal laws
Treat humanity never merely as means, but always as an end
Duty calls us to act from moral law, not consequences

name: Mill
worldview_values: Greatest happiness principle, individual liberty, harm principle
example_lines: Actions are right in proportion as they promote happiness
The only purpose for which power can be rightfully exercised over others is to prevent harm
Better to be a human being dissatisfied than a pig satisfied

name: Aristotle
example_lines: Virtue lies in the mean between extremes
We are what we repeatedly do. Excellence is not an act, but a habit
The good life requires both virtue and external goods

name: Rawls
worldview_values: Justice as fairness, original position, veil of ignorance
example_lines: Justice is the first virtue of social institutions
Behind the veil of ignorance, what principles would we choose?
The difference principle allows inequalities only if they benefit the least advantaged

name: Singer
worldview_values: Preference utilitarianism, effective altruism, animal rights
example_lines: The principle of equal consideration of interests applies to all sentient beings
We must expand our circle of moral concern
Effective altruism demands we do the most good possible

name: Bentham
worldview_values: Hedonic calculus, legal positivism, prison reform
example_lines: It is the greatest happiness of the greatest number that is the measure of right and wrong
Nature has placed mankind under two sovereign masters: pain and pleasure
Every law is contrary to liberty

name: Nozick
example_lines: Individuals have rights, and there are things no person or group may do to them
Taxation of earnings from labor is on a par with forced labor
The minimal state is the most extensive state that can be justified

name: Parfit
worldview_values: Personal identity puzzles, population ethics, triple theory
example_lines: What matters is not survival, but psychological continuity and connectedness
We should reject the non-identity problem's troubling implications
Personal identity is not what matters for survival

name: Hippocrates
worldview_values: Medical ethics, natural healing, do no harm
example_lines: First, do no harm
Healing is a matter of time, but sometimes opportunity
The physician must be ready to tell the truth
